title: David's Military and Administrative Organization
shortSummary: 1 Chronicles 27 details the organization of King David's military divisions and tribal leaders, highlighting the systematic governance and stewardship under his reign. It reveals the orderliness God established in David’s kingdom, emphasizing faithful leadership and divine provision for Israel’s security and prosperity.
timeline: c. 1010-970 BC - Reign of King David in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Jashobeam
keyCharacters.description: Commander of the first military division during the first month, noted as a chief captain of thousands.

keyCharacters.name: Benaiah
keyCharacters.description: A prominent military leader, chief priest, and captain of the third month’s division, known for his valor among David’s mighty men.

keyCharacters.name: Joab
keyCharacters.description: David’s general of the army, responsible for military leadership and also involved in the census that incurred God’s wrath.

keyCharacters.name: Azmaveth
keyCharacters.description: Overseer of the king’s treasures, responsible for managing David’s wealth and resources.

definitions.definition: A military division or rotation of troops assigned to serve the king for a specific month.
Military leaders commanding units of a thousand or a hundred soldiers, responsible for discipline and leadership.
A member of a clan or family group, here referring to Dodai’s lineage.
Facilities used for storing provisions, supplies, and goods necessary for the kingdom’s functioning.

outline.heading: Organization of the Military Divisions by Month
outline.description: This section lists the twelve military divisions, each serving one month of the year, with 24,000 men per division, highlighting the structured defense system under David’s command.

outline.heading: Tribal Leaders of Israel
outline.description: The chapter names the rulers of each of Israel’s twelve tribes, emphasizing the tribal governance and unity within the kingdom.

outline.heading: The Census and Divine Displeasure
outline.description: David’s census of the people is mentioned but left incomplete due to God’s displeasure, reminding readers of the importance of trusting God’s promises rather than relying solely on numbers.

outline.heading: Administration of the King’s Resources
outline.description: This section details officials in charge of various economic resources such as treasures, fields, vineyards, and livestock, showing the comprehensive management of the kingdom’s wealth.

outline.heading: David’s Counselors and Military Leadership
outline.description: The chapter concludes by naming David’s key advisors and military leaders, underscoring the wisdom and support behind his reign.

application: Trust in God’s provision and leadership rather than relying solely on human strength or numbers, as seen in David’s incomplete census.
Recognize the importance of orderly stewardship and faithful service in every area of life, mirroring the careful administration under David.
Value godly counsel and wise advisors in decision-making to lead with integrity and wisdom.
Commit to serving faithfully in whatever role God has assigned, whether in leadership or support, knowing every part contributes to His kingdom.

keyVerses.text: But David took not the number of them from twenty years old and under: because the LORD had said he would increase Israel like to the stars of the heavens.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s promise of blessing and growth, encouraging trust in His sovereign provision rather than human calculations.

keyVerses.text: And after Ahithophel was Jehoiada the son of Benaiah, and Abiathar: and the general of the king's army was Joab.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the importance of godly leadership and counsel in maintaining the strength and stability of the kingdom.

keyVerses.text: Now the children of Israel after their number, to wit, the chief fathers and captains of thousands and hundreds, and their officers that served the king in any matter of the courses, which came in and went out month by month throughout all the months of the year, of every course were twenty and four thousand.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the tone for the chapter, showing the organized and systematic nature of David’s military and administrative structure.
